title: MODULE 10
subtitle: Facing Trauma: Taking a Step Back to Move Forward
description: This module was assigned to you because you have experienced a traumatic event or ongoing trauma that may be impacting your well-being. You will be asked to think about things that may be disturbing or upsetting. The main purpose of this module is to educate you about trauma, its possible impacts, and when more intensive treatment would be a good idea. This module is not going to help you “get over” trauma. If you become distressed at any point, call a trusted friend, your supervision officer, or dial 988 for a 24-hour crisis hotline. You got this!

pages.text:
This module talks about how extremely difficult experiences can impact the way people think, feel, and act. Remember the Circle of Change? It can also be used to demonstrate the need to change thoughts, feelings, and behavior to stop the cycle of these experiences impacting your life. Visit My Journal for writing space so you can record your thoughts and feelings and The Resource Center for meditation and calming exercises. You should also tell your probation officer and/or counselor that you are working on trauma so they can help you when you need it. If you feel comfortable, tell people you trust that you are starting this work. You don’t need to tell them everything about your trauma, just that you are embarking on this journey. Their support will help.
**This module is not meant to replace seeing a counselor. It is meant to bring awareness to trauma and help you understand it and it can be hurtful. The module will teach you some skills, but this will likely not be enough for you. Talking to your supervising officer or a quick internet search may help you find someone in your area or through telehealth who can best help you. You may also be able to find a trauma survivor’s support group in your area.**
pages.subheader: Understanding Trauma and Trauma Work: Proceed with Caution and at Your Own Pace

questions.prompt:
Some people do not like thinking about their past for lots of reasons. Some people had to grow up fast and did not have an enjoyable or loving childhood. Others experienced abuse at some point in their lives, such as being physically abused by a parent or being forced to have unwanted sex with a romantic partner or stranger. Sometimes, these experiences are so bad or hurtful to people, they are considered trauma.
Trauma is a deeply distressing or disturbing event or series of events that causes physical and/or emotional pain for the person who experienced it. Yes—trauma can be emotional or so-called “psychological.” It does not need to involve actual physical violence. Trauma can range from everyday life circumstances (like living in a bad neighborhood or being bullied) to events where your life is at risk. Trauma is less about the actual event and more about how the event impacts the person who experienced it. It’s important to know that some people respond to bad situations differently. The same event may cause lasting distress for one person but may have little to no impact on another. A reaction to a traumatic event can also happen at different times. Some people respond to trauma right away, while others may react later. Trauma for some people takes time to “sink in.” For still others, it may take time to even realize that what happened to them was wrong. Just because you didn’t have a big reaction at the time of the event, doesn’t mean you can’t have one later or that your response is any less important.
Examples of events that are usually seen as traumatic include:
  • • Being hit, beaten, burned, or severely punished by an adult, parent, or babysitter.
  • Being told you are worthless, unloved, unimportant, or other hurtful things by an adult or important family member.
  • Being forced to accept or participate in sex or sex acts with another person, including friends, family members, romantic partners, and strangers.
  • Being forced to be by yourself for excessively long periods of time (like days without human contact), whether it was because of military training, prison procedures, or punishment from a parent.
  • Being neglected as a child such that you went without clean clothes, food, water, or stable housing.
  • A serious accident or natural disaster, like earthquakes, hurricanes, tornadoes, car accidents, or house fires.
  • A life-threatening incident or a near-death experience, such as being robbed at gunpoint or nearly falling off of a cliff while hiking.
  • Watching someone else - a stranger or someone you care about - in a serious accident or natural disaster or have a life-threatening or near-death experience.
  • Watching someone die or get seriously injured.
  • Oppression or marginalization caused by racism, sexism, or other forms of discrimination.
If you have experienced any of the events listed above or similar events in your life, you may have a lot going through your mind right now. Feeling stressed out, anxious, depressed, or nervous are all common responses to trauma. A lot of people who have experienced a traumatic event will replay the event in their mind, have dreams where they relive the experience, or become paranoid when reminded of these experiences. People may experience sadness, social isolation, or no longer enjoy things they used to enjoy (signs of depression), and other people may experience nervousness, shakiness, worrying, and intrusive thoughts (signs of anxiety), all because of an event or series of events that happened to them. Trauma can also make people feel numb or disconnected from reality—like nothing bad ever happened. Particularly if you have been living in a traumatic experience for a while, you may begin to see it as normal. If you’ve had events like this happen to you before, it’s also okay if you are not having any negative reactions right now. Whatever emotions you are feeling or not feeling is okay. This module will encourage you to explore your feelings.

fields.text: Have you experienced any of the events listed above or any other events you would consider to be traumatic? Until we go over more skills to deal with trauma, keep your answer brief for now. Only write down information you are comfortable sharing.

pages.text:
Some traumatic events are rare, but it is common for people to experience at least one traumatic event in their lifetime. In fact, more than half of all men and women in the U.S. have experienced at least one type of traumatic event. Research tells us some traumatic events are more likely to happen to men and some are more likely to happen to women.
Men are more likely to experience trauma in the forms of...
  • Physical accidents and injuries
  • Physical punishment in childhood
  • Nonsexual assault
  • Domestic violence while growing up
  • Witnessing someone's injury or death
  • Substance abuse (like alcohol) in immediate family
  • Natural disasters and fires
  • Combat exposure and war-related trauma.
Women are more likely to experience trauma in the forms of...
  • Sexual assault
  • Parental conflict growing up
  • Child sexual abuse
BUT, research also shows that all people experience all forms of trauma. Some men are also victims of child sexual abuse and sexual assault, and some women are also victims of combat exposure and war-related trauma. So, while it's true that some trauma is more likely to happen to men or women, anyone can be negatively affected by traumatic events and there are no rules on who is allowed to be impacted by certain events. We also know from research that 90% of people with a mental illness have experienced at least one type of traumatic event. Although we do not yet know why people with mental illnesses are more likely to live through traumatic experiences, we do know that experiencing a traumatic event can make a mental illness worse or trigger a mental illness. If you ignore your symptoms, stuff down your emotions, or don't talk about your trauma with others, it can keep you from feeling better emotionally and physically and moving on with your life in a healthy way. Part of being on supervision is to create a healthier and safer lifestyle, so not working through your feelings may make it harder to be successful on community supervision.

Below are several misconceptions, or fibs, about traumatic events. Believing these fibs can discourage people from talking about what happened to them or seeking help. Write down a counter argument to each fib that shows why it's not true. This first one is done for you as an example.

questions.prompt:
Example: Talking about trauma will be harmful to me.
Counter argument: "Talking about trauma may be painful or difficult at first, but it will be more helpful in the long run."

fields.text:
Time heals all wounds, so it's not worth it to dwell on the past.
Counter argument:

People who experience trauma need to get over it and move on.
Counter argument:

Men aren't allowed to be affected by trauma or talk about what happened. (hint: think about the "tough guy" attitude from Understanding My Emotions).
Counter argument:

Trauma experiences are just part of the job (military, police force, fire force).
Counter argument:

Gang violence and related trauma is just part of growing up in the "hood" or on the streets.
Counter argument:

What happened was my fault, so I don't get to feel bad or complain about the event.
Counter argument:

pages.subheader: The Trauma of Talking about Trauma

questions.prompt: It can be hard to talk about traumatic events for a variety of reasons. Traumatic events are often very serious events in people’s lives, as they can include abuse, pain, betrayal, witnessing the death of a loved one or the threat of your own death. Because they are so serious, people who have experienced trauma often feel distressed when thinking or talking about it. As you may have noticed so far, just reading about examples of trauma can make us feel uneasy, worrisome, unsafe, or mad. These feelings can be uncomfortable for people, which is why they avoid talking about it. While avoiding the discomfort feels better in the moment, it is not very helpful in the long-term. Trauma will pop up again, sometimes when you least expect it.

fields.text: If you have experienced a traumatic event, who have you talked to about the event? You don’t need to share a specific name. For example, you could say “my best friend” or “my favorite aunt.” If you haven’t told anyone yet, who have you considered telling?
If you spoke up about your trauma, how did the other person react? If you have not spoken up yet, how do you expect others will react?

questions.prompt: Like many other things in life, there are both benefits and drawbacks to talking about trauma. Based on what you've read so far and your experiences, why might you find it helpful to keep your trauma to yourself? And, how much more helpful could it be to talk it out? List out benefits of both options.

fields.text: What do you GAIN by not talking about trauma?
What MORE do you GAIN by talking about trauma?

Notice that, despite the fact that there may be some benefits to keeping trauma to yourself, the scale should be tilted in favor of the benefits of talking them out. For example, you may want to keep things to yourself for fear of judgment or that others could blame you, but if you share with people you trust, you may find the support you need. Usually, the benefits you get from bottling things in make you feel worse in the long-run and stop you from moving forward.

pages.text: Before you start thinking about bad memories, there is a VERY important skill to help you work through this module. When people work through bad memories, it can cause these bad memories—and new ones you hadn’t even thought of yet—to pop up in your head at random times like at work, at your mom’s big birthday party, or while meeting with your supervision officer. You may be tempted to think about your trauma memories during these random times, but this can lead to uncomfortable feelings that you are not able to cope with in the moment. You need time to calm back down and get back on track. It’s like being out to sea without a life raft. When trauma-related feelings surface at inconvenient times, you use a time-out box to keep those bad memories from bothering you or the people around you. A time-out box can lock up whatever thoughts or emotions are upsetting to you for a good and long time out. You have the key and can unlock it later when you're ready to think about those thoughts and feel those emotions. Remember, this box is to temporarily hold back memories and feelings, not to permanently forget about them. The box is so your emotions don’t get the better of you at the wrong times.
pages.subheader: The Right Place and Head Space

questions.prompt: In your head, picture a box of any kind. It can be a treasure chest, a safe, or just a plain wooden box. Now, give your box a lid or a door, something that can close tightly. Next, give it a lock. It can be a simple key lock, a combination lock, or a fancy fingerprint scanning lock – whatever will be strong enough to keep something bad locked away.

fields.text: Which box looks more secure?
What does your time-out box look like? Think about which of these you would rather have for your box. Does it meet all of the qualifications?
Is it open or closed?
Is it made of cardboard, wood, or metal?
What does your lock look like?

Let’s test your time-out box. Think of a person who just irritated the living hell out of you. It can be a real person or a fake person—like a cartoon character or a type of person (doctors, lawyers, your probation officer!). Think about why that person gets under your skin or the last thing they did to burn you. How did that moment make you feel? What thoughts do you have about that irritating person? Now, imagine yourself opening up your box and putting those feelings of irritation, anger, and all the thoughts and reminders of that person in the box. Close the lid tight, and make sure the lock is secure. When your feelings about this person or words they have said are in the time-out box, you can attend to other thoughts that are more important in the moment. The time-out box only works if you train your mind to think about other things and not the thing in the box. After a few minutes, you should find that you relax and don’t feel as angry anymore. Then, you can finish doing what you were doing before you got upset, and you have a positive, productive day. In a way, this technique is a bit like thought stopping. You can say, “No, I’m not thinking about this now. I don’t have time. It’s going in the box!” Remember the box will help you set aside traumatic thoughts and reactions when the time is not right; it is not meant to lock away these thoughts forever. You have the key and can open the box again when it’s appropriate to do so.

pages.text:
At the end of each activity, navigate to you the thought log tab (with the pencil icon) on the dashboard to track triggers throughout the week. For each triggering event, record what you thought of in the moment, what emotions you felt, and how you coped with the thoughts and feelings. Then, record the outcome - did you feel better after coping, or did your choice of coping mechanism make you feel worse?
Navigate to the thought log now.

It is easy to continue ignoring feelings and thoughts related to trauma, or pretending it never happened. Not only can this hurt you more in the long run (like make mental illness worse, complicate relationships, risk violating community supervision terms), but research tells us that when people successfully work through their trauma, parts of their personality—believe It or not!—change for the better. This change is called “post-traumatic growth.” Similar to Oji, trauma work may help you reinvent part of yourself.
Common traits of people who work through trauma include:
  • A new appreciation for life
  • More fulfilling social relationships
  • Feelings of greater emotional and mental strength
  • Greater spiritual connection (with a higher power, with their inner soul)
  • Seeing new possibilities and opportunities in their future
  • A new wisdom about the world around them
  • Greater overall life satisfaction
Scientists still do not know exactly what causes post-traumatic growth. But one thing is certain: if working through trauma will not only reduce negative effects, but increase positive effects for you, isn’t it worth a shot to try?
pages.subheader: Collecting Your Coping Skills: Why Bother with Trauma Work?

pages.text: As we discussed before, there are some challenges that come with trauma work. It is helpful to have tools to manage the symptoms of trauma, improve the way you see yourself, and make you feel empowered rather than held back by the trauma you have experienced. This work is very difficult, and you will probably feel worse before you feel better. Taking a few steps back to make strides forward is how this process works. It is important to have good coping skills already in place to use when disturbing feelings arise. And remember, you are strongly encouraged to seek out individual therapy in addition to this module or enroll in a support group.

questions.prompt: List at least 4 coping skills or strategies you've learned in this program so far that could help you if things get tough:

fields.text: Coping Skill #1:
Coping Skill #2:
Coping Skill #3:
Coping Skill #4:

questions.prompt: Now, try to list 4 supportive people you can talk to about this module, your trauma, and any questions or struggles you may have during this module:

fields.text: Go-to person #1:
Go-to person #2:
Go-to person #3:
Go-to person #4:

pages.text: Although this does not happen often, sometimes people who work through trauma begin to have thoughts of harming themselves. People who have had suicidal thoughts or harmed themselves before are more likely to experience these thoughts and urges while processing trauma. If you completed the Suicide and Self-Injurious Behavior Module, you should be familiar with your suicide prevention plan. Review your plan so it's fresh in your mind. If you didn't complete this module because your supervising officer said it wasn't required, then the space below is blank for you. Create a prevention plan below. Regardless of whether you feel suicidal, this plan is a reminder of what to do and who to call if you get to a place where things are unmanageable. Don’t let this possibility scare you. Again, this risk is very low. By this point in the program, you have a lot of good quality skills to use when you feel bad. You’ve come a long way and have learned a lot about yourself. You know who you are and have control over what you do next.
pages.subheader: A Warning of Possible Higher Risks

questions.prompt: If you did complete the Suicide and Self-Injurious Behavior module, please type "N/A" below.

fields.text: Prevention Plan:

pages.text: Now that you’ve finished this activity, start a new entry in your weekly Thought Log. Remember, for each triggering event, record what you thought of in the moment, what emotions you felt, and how you coped with the thoughts and feelings. Then, record the outcome - did you feel better after coping, or did your choice of coping mechanism make you feel worse?

Some people are very aware of the trauma they have experienced. Other people may feel their trauma is so stressful or upsetting that they try to pretend it never happened—they know something bad happened but keep their experience hidden to feel protected. In other words, people put these thoughts and feelings about trauma into a box and avoid opening it again. Avoidance is different from your time-out box. The time-out box is temporary and only used when it’s not the right time or place to think about trauma. You have the key to this box and can re-open it when you’re ready. People who choose to ignore their reactions to trauma want to keep the box closed forever.
Other people may acknowledge the event but insist nothing bad happened or that the event was justified. So, they don’t see the event as traumatic. A wife forced to have sex by her husband may see it has part of her wifely duties rather than as abusive. In very rare cases, people may forget the event completely. These are called ¬repressed memories. Forgetting about the trauma can be the brain’s way of protecting you from thinking about something terrible that you witnessed or went through. But repressed memories are not helpful because they keep you from getting help. However, be careful not to allow people to put bad memories of things that never actually happened in your head! Our minds are fragile and research shows that we can sometimes “remember” things that never happened to us. Be open to the possibility that you may not remember everything about a traumatic event, but don’t let other people (especially people who weren't even there!) “feed” details of an event to you; your brain may just fill in the gaps with details that aren’t true.
pages.subheader: Trauma Avoidance: Not Talking can be Harmful

pages.text:
In this exercise, use your mental traffic light to determine if your thoughts about your traumatic event are protective or harmful. Below are some examples of what might be considered as green, yellow, and red behaviors.
  • Green- I know I have experienced trauma, and I have told the people who need to know like my doctor, my probation officer, a trusted friend, or family member.
  • Yellow- I know I have experienced trauma, but I do not talk about it. No one knows what happened, and that makes me feel comfortable.
  • Red- What happened was my fault, so when people try to tell me it's not, I get angry and stop listening. How can it really be “trauma” if I played a part in it? I get tired of other people making it a bigger deal than it was.

fields.text: In the space below, describe your current thinking about the bad thing(s) you experienced. Even if you do not consider the events to be traumatic, write down any thoughts that come to mind when you reflect on how it has impacted you and where you are in your desire to talk about it with others.
Re-read your statement above and review the mental traffic light. Click whether you’d label this thought as Green, Yellow, or Red.
What makes your statement a red, yellow, or green light?

questions.prompt: Now, write down whether you EVER experienced a red, yellow, or green light thought related to your trauma or an experience that was really bad for you.

fields.text: A RED light thought I've had is:
A YELLOW light thought I've had is:
A GREEN light thought I've had is:

pages.text: Now that you’ve finished this activity, start a new entry in your weekly Thought Log. Remember, for each triggering event, record what you thought of in the moment, what emotions you felt, and how you coped with the thoughts and feelings. Then, record the outcome - did you feel better after coping, or did your choice of coping mechanism make you feel worse?

When people experience events where they fear or witness serious injury or death, it can really mess with how people think or feel about the event, themselves, or others. It can even change people's behavior and decisions. Take Cecil, for example:
Cecil's best friend and roommate, Irvin, has been taking several medications regularly for pain and anxiety after a bad car accident. One morning, Irvin took forever in the bathroom. Cecil was pissed because he had to get ready for work too but couldn't because Irvin was taking too long. Cecil finally pounded on the bathroom door and yelled "Dude, hurry the hell up! You're not the only one with a life!" Irvin didn't say anything back, and Cecil didn't hear any movement in the bathroom. Cecil opened the door and saw Irvin lying on the bathroom floor in a puddle of vomit. Cecil started to panic thinking Irvin was dead. Cecil called emergency services and an ambulance picked up Irvin. It turns out Irvin's medications led to a bad reaction when he took them all together, causing him to lose consciousness. Now, two months later, Cecil still "jumps" when he open the bathroom door in his home. He constantly feels guilty about how rude he had been to Irvin that morning, and refuses to take any medications because he worries they will kill him.
pages.subheader: How Trauma Has Affected You: The Impact of Trauma

fields.text: What traumatic event did Cecil experience?
How did the event change the way Cecil thought in the future?
How did the event change the way Cecil felt in the future?
How did the event change the way Cecil behaved in the future?
How did the event change the way Cecil made decisions in the future?

pages.text:
Sometimes, traumatic events can even change what we think is the truth. Notice that Cecil thought that taking any medication would kill him? In reality, thousands of medications are safe to take and have minimal side effects. Many medications can even be taken together without serious side effects when monitored by a physician. But the traumatic event made it hard for Cecil to believe this. People can also alter or misinterpret facts about who "caused" a traumatic event or who is to blame. The fact that Cecil continues feeling guilty for being rude to Irvin sends the signal "If I weren't rude to Irvin, he would have never gotten sick." Even though this is impossible (treating someone poorly does not change the way their medications will affect their body), Cecil still blames himself.
Research shows that there are some ways in which a person's view of the world can be most often changed by trauma. These include feelings of safety, control, and self-esteem, as well as attitudes toward trusting others, power, and intimacy in relationships. These are discussed next.
  • Safety: Feelings of safety include whether you feel you can keep yourself or others safe, and whether you feel other people care about or are capable of keeping you safe. Trauma, especially that involving physical accidents, injury, or death, can send the message "I don’t have the ability to keep myself safe" or "other people/things are only out to hurt me." You may take extra precautions to do everyday tasks or avoid any situation that may be risky at all like not leaving the house after 4pm so you're always home before dark.
  • Control: Most people feel generally in control of their own life and what happens to them. Trauma can make you feel like life is out of your control, such as when natural disasters strike or other people's wreckless mistakes hurt you or your loved ones. You may start thinking "no matter how hard I try, I'll never get what I need or want out of life" or "no matter what I do, people will treat me however they want or just leave." This may lead to strong emotional reactions and rash decisions in relationships, like breaking up with a dating partner the first time they tell you “no” or disagree with you.
  • Self-Esteem: Some people may, without any trauma, struggle with low self-esteem, or feeling badly about themselves and their abilities. This can get worse when people believe they were at fault for traumatic events or were not strong enough, smart enough, or quick enough to prevent it from happening. These feelings can last years. It may also change the way you see other people, which is called "other-esteem." If a traumatic event involved a perpetrator who mistreated you or violated your rights, you may have negative attitudes about people similar to the perpetrator, or just others generally: for example, "all men want is to take sex and leave" or "everyone is just selfish and out for themselves." People whose self-esteem has been hurt because of trauma dismiss or "explain away" compliments, don't understand how others can see good qualities in them, and may struggle with feelings of depression.
  • Trust: Trust toward yourself and others can change after trauma, especially if the event involved someone you knew, like an acquaintance or family member. You may not trust your judgment of others' character, perceptions of situations, or your decision-making. Often times, trust toward others may lead you to think you cannot trust other people under any circumstances. This could lead to avoiding new relationships, saying hurtful things to people in your family or social network who don’t deserve it, and doing extra tasks or work (walking to the supervision office rather than asking for a ride, paying rent for your roommates) because you are unwilling to test the trust of others and expect them to not follow through.
  • Power: Similar to control, after trauma some people feel they are physically or mentally weak, or have no influence on how they do in school, at work, on probation, or at home. After traumatic events, thoughts may look like "no one cares what I think, so why bother saying it" and "I don't have the skills or ability to change my direction on supervision." You may find yourself either giving up in areas where you feel you do not have any power or trying extra hard to regain power, such as by giving people ultimatums or acting aggressively in relationships.
  • Intimacy: Intimacy is the experience of being close with someone, either emotionally or physically. It can include things like confiding in others, opening up about how you feel or think, or having sex with someone. Physical, sexual, or emotional abuse by a parent, sibling, spouse, or even stranger sends a clear message that intimacy in any form is dangerous and should be avoided. People who struggle with intimacy after trauma think things like "I have to hide the real me because if she knew who I was, she would leave me" or "I don't think I could ever have sex with a trusting partner and enjoy it the way I should." Sometimes trauma can also lead people to use sex or romance as a coping mechanism, but often these relationships are not deep, genuine connections.

Write down some of the ways the traumatic event you experienced changed the way you think about and look at the world around you. Reminder: If at any point this becomes stressful, think back to your coping skills reviewed in this module.

fields.text: HOW has the event impacted the way you THINK?

List which of the following "world views" did the event change?
  • Safety
  • Control
  • Self-esteem
  • Trust
  • Power
  • Intimacy
If you chose safety, what are your new views on the topic? If you did not choose it, type "N/A"
If you chose control, what are your new views on the topic? If you did not choose it, type "N/A"
If you chose self-esteem, what are your new views on the topic? If you did not choose it, type "N/A"
If you chose trust, what are your new views on the topic? If you did not choose it, type "N/A"
If you chose power, what are your new views on the topic? If you did not choose it, type "N/A"
If you chose intimacy, what are your new views on the topic? If you did not choose it, type "N/A"
HOW has the event has impacted the way you FEEL?
HOW has the event has impacted the way you BEHAVE?
HOW has the event has impacted the way you MAKE DECISIONS?

pages.text: Now that you’ve finished this activity, start a new entry in your weekly Thought Log. Remember, for each triggering event, record what you thought of in the moment, what emotions you felt, and how you coped with the thoughts and feelings. Then, record the outcome - did you feel better after coping, or did your choice of coping mechanism make you feel worse?

In the previous worksheet, the different ways trauma can change the way you think, feel, behave, and make decisions were discussed. You even identified some of the specific ways in which your thoughts and feelings have been changed. Even after that, you may be wondering 'so what?' You may be tempted to just accept these changes and live your life in this new, changed way. However, this may not be the best decision for you and the life you want to lead after completing supervision.
pages.subheader: Can the Impact of Trauma Really Hold Me Back?

pages.text:
It may seem that negative thoughts and feelings associated with your trauma only affect you. But this type of thinking is not accurate! Just like Oji, you do not live in a bubble with yourself - you have both small and large circles of friends and family, as well as the community where you live. Your negative thoughts, feelings, and behavior take place in these circles, you cannot avoid impacting others with your decisions. For example, if your trauma leads you to believe others cannot be trusted to follow through on their word, you may be unwilling to work on team projects or end up treating your coworkers poorly when they miss a deadline: "Of course you missed It! You're just as good as the rest of them. I don't know why I bother anymore." Not only do these behaviors make the workplace uncomfortable for others, it will probably show up on your work evaluation the next time you want a promotion.
Negative impacts can happen at home with family, too. After trauma, some people believe others are only out to control or manipulate them, or that they cannot be honest with or confide in others. They may become stressed, angry, and withdraw from dating partners or their spouse when they start to feel they are no longer in control of the relationship. Their partner or spouse, confused and hurt, may behave in unhealthy ways or end the relationship. The children involved may learn mixed messages about what a healthy relationship looks like and grow up to have control issues of their own. The person who originally experienced the trauma is left feeling confused and abandoned, and is probably that much more convinced that they cannot get too close to people for fear of being hurt or left.
pages.subheader: Who Feels the Impact of Trauma?

pages.text: Changes in the way you feel and behave after a traumatic event can be explained by one or several changes in your thinking that may have emerged from the trauma itself. These thoughts are called "sinkholes." You can tell the difference between sinkholes and helpful thoughts because sinkholes make you feel "stuck" on negative emotions and blaming yourself, while helpful thoughts bring up positive or neutral (neither good or bad) emotions and help you to move on from the event in a healthy way. Sinkholes make it harder to process trauma. Think about driving down a stretch of highway. Your journey is going smoothly until you hit a huge pothole in the road, causing you to swerve off course. If this long, winding road is the path to recovery from trauma, a sinkhole or pothole, in the road is a thought or habit that makes it harder to finish driving down this road and achieving recovery.

Five different types of sinkholes include:
  • Black and white thinking- this is also known as "all or nothing" thinking, these types of thoughts prevent people from seeing the "gray" area in a situation. For example, "I'll never get a job to pay for my probation fees" or "My probation officer always writes me up for stupid mistakes."
  • Not using "I" statements- "I" statements are used to help people focus on their own thoughts and feelings rather than on another person. When people don't focus on their own thoughts and feelings, they risk not taking responsibility for their own feelings and actions (an example of criminal thinking) or avoiding how they think and feel. For example, "You ake me so made when you show up to my work unannounced" rather than "I feel embarrassed when you visit my work because I don't tell people I'm on community supervision" or ”Because my friends wouldn’t just leave me alone, I got in trouble with my probation officer” rather than ”Because I did not tell my friends what contact was okay and not okay, I violated the terms of my probation agreement.”
  • Predicting the future- These type of thoughts involve blaming other people or yourself for things that could not have been foreseen. When you expect others or yourself to know what will happen in the future, it takes away from your ability to truly examine the situation, who was actually responsible for events, who should feel guilty about the events, and how to avoid similar events in the future. For example, ”You should have known that the semi-truck would come into your lane like that!” or ”I can't believe I thought she would actually be sober this time around.”
  • Exaggerating OR minimizing- These thoughts make the facts of the event MUCH worse (exaggerating) or better (minimizing) than what they actually were. Exaggerating and minimizing prevents people from being honest about their trauma and can make it easier to avoid working through it. For example, ”I mean, yeah, I told him I didn’t want to have sex with him but we were both drunk. It could have been so much worse” or ”You don't understand, I nearly died in that car accident. No, I didn't need medical attention, but you weren't there. You wouldn't know how horrible it was.”
  • Emotional reasoning - These are thoughts that rely on emotions to determine if they are true. While emotions are important to think about and consider when talking about trauma, emotions do not always reflect the truth (especially for events that are scary or traumatic). These are thoughts that rely on emotions to determine if they are true. While emotions are important to think about and consider when talking about trauma, emotions do not always reflect the truth (especially for events that are scary or traumatic). For example, ”I really did love her - she didn't mean to hurt me when she hit me” or ”Ever since the elevator accident, I feel so scared going into one. I just know the elevator will collapse at any minute.”

questions.prompt: In the spaces below, list the sinkholes you can identify in your own thinking about your trauma. Select what type of sinkhole it is from the multiple choice question under each answer. Feel free to visit the previous page and reference the examples listed earlier to help you correctly label your sinkhole. If you can identify more sinkholes than the space allows, use the journal feature to finish listing your sinkholes.

fields.text: Sinkhole #1:
What type of sinkhole is it?
Sinkhole #2:
What type of sinkhole is it?
Sinkhole #3:
What type of sinkhole is it?
Sinkhole #4:
What type of sinkhole is it?
Sinkhole #5:
What type of sinkhole is it?

pages.text:
Sinkholes create pits in the road to recovering from trauma. You can fall into these pits making your journey take longer than it has to be.
Antoinette has been on community supervision for 18 months. At her last meeting with her supervising officer, Antoinette was told that her court hearing to be released from supervision will be requested this week. Excitedly, Antoinette called her best friend Carlos to tell him the good news. Carlos answered the phone and listened to Antoinette, but seemed distracted. Suddenly, Antoinette heard Carlos shout ”what the fuck?! Shit!” Carlos could no longer be heard on the phone, and sounds of scraping metal and breaking glass were heard. Antoinette panicked, but had no idea what she could do to check on Carlos. Antoinette later found out that Carlos was talking to her while driving down the interstate, and was cut off by a semi-truck which then stopped suddenly. Carlos didn't react in time and rear-ended the semi-truck going 60 miles per hour. Carlos recovered from the accident a few weeks later, but Antoinette found herself feeling guilty about the pain Carlos went through, all because she called him on the phone. She tells herself that Carlos' accident is all her fault. Antoinette refuses to call people unless she knows for a fact that they are home and experiences a lot of anxiety when riding in the passenger seat of her friends' cars.

fields.text: What sinkhole(s) did Antoinette get stuck in?

If you said, black and white thinking, predicting the future, or exaggerating, nice work! If you didn’t get it this time, don’t worry. We have plenty of time to practice more. So, what do you do if you are running into sinkholes? First, ask yourself some important questions before you trust that your thought is true. Try answering these questions for Antoinette based on her traumatic event.
Antoinette believes she is at fault for her friend's accident. How is this an example of a ”predicting the future” sinkhole?
What is the evidence that Antoinette is at fault for her friend’s accident?
What is the evidence that Antoinette is NOT at fault for her friend’s accident?
Because of the sinkholes, what information is Antoinette failing to consider about what caused the event?
Is Antoinette’s thought that she is to blame based on information, feelings, or viewpoints that are unrelated to what actually happened?
What might be a helpful ”I” statement for Antoinette in this situation?
When you find yourself in one of your own sinkholes, ask yourself these questions. If they sound familiar, good! They are similar to your Thought Logs.
Chose one of your sinkholes listed previously.
What is the evidence that this thought is true?
What is the evidence that this thought is NOT true?
What information am I failing to consider about the event?
Is my thought based on information, feelings, or viewpoints that are unrelated to what actually happened?
Can I phrase my thought or feeling in an ”I” statement?

pages.text:
If the questions on the previous page revealed that your sinkhole is not very trustworthy or truthful, your sinkhole is likely more an empty pit than a sturdy patch of ground. So, replace the sinkhole with a road patch, or a new sentence that is more truthful and helps you continue your road to recovery. Below are some examples to help you.
Example 1:
  • Sinkhole: If I hadn't called my buddy that day, he wouldn't have answered the phone while driving and gotten into that nasty wreck.
  • Road Patch: I feel really bad that my friend got into that car accident. I didn't know he was driving, and even if I did, I wouldn't have wanted him to answer until he was finished.

Example 2:
  • Sinkhole: I can never go on another date, or I'll get raped again.
  • Road Patch: Not all dating partners violate the rights of or disrespect others, and not all sexual assaults happen while on a date. Because I want to protect myself, I will only go on dates in public spaces and will drive myself to and from the date.

questions.prompt: Now, create a road patch you can use to start filling in the sinkhole you identified earlier and help you recover from your trauma:

fields.text: Sinkhole:
Road Patch:

pages.text:
You've practiced a lot on identifying and repairing sinkholes. Now, when you find yourself in sinkholes at work, during community supervision meetings, or when you feel overwhelmed by your trauma, use these steps to repair your sinkholes:
  • Identify what type of sinkhole you are in.
  • Ask yourself questions to decide what's true and not true about the sinkhole, you might use a Thought Log to help you sort this part out.
  • Create a road patch that helps you out of the sinkhole now and avoid it again later.

The brain is programmed with different shortcuts so it can learn lots of information quickly. For example, when two things happen at the same time or close together in time, the brain may link those two things together. For some people in some situations, the process of connecting two things with each other can take a long time. However, for other people in other situations, it only takes one experience to associate two things with each other. Have you ever gotten sick after eating a certain food, like sushi or a cheeseburger? It was probably hard to eat that same food again after getting sick—all you can think of is the way it tasted coming back up! In a classic psychology experiment (which would not be allowed today) scientists gave a little boy a white rat to play with. As the boy was joyfully playing with the animal, someone made a loud, unpleasant noise behind him and it startled him. Eventually, with enough pairings of the rat and the terrible noise, ”little Albert” (as he was known) not only became scared of the white rat, but he was also scared of white bunnies and even Santa Claus’s beard because they reminded him of the scary loud noises. Now, there is plenty of research to show how harmful it is to create fear in people, and many treatments have been developed to reduce, and sometimes even eliminate, fear reactions and negative associations. Fear does not have to last forever.
These connections in your brain can also occur when a traumatic event happens. It could take just one time, or multiple times, for it to affect you. In many cases, something REALLY bad only needs to happen one time for your brain to connect details of the event (where it took place, what you smelled, what you saw, what you heard) with the feelings you had during the traumatic event (fear, anger, shock, sadness). Here’s an example:
Growing up, Yasmin’s mother used Smells So Fresh laundry detergent every week to wash her and her sibling’s clothes and bed sheets. Yasmin’s father was never in the picture, but her mom always had lots of male friends over to the house. She remembers witnessing her mother’s boyfriends smack her around. Sometimes they would hurl cruel insults at her mother and sometimes they would hit her, pull her hair, or firmly grab her arm. She remembers hiding in the laundry room when arguments between the adults in the house would break out. Yasmin is now 32 years old and lives on her own. Every time she smells the scent of Smells So Fresh detergent, she is rushed with feelings of terror, guilt, and anger. She normally avoids buying this brand herself, but one time she was at a neighbor’s house and caught a whiff of a blanket that draped over the neighbor’s couch. She immediately began to feel uneasy and irritable. Yasmin made up an excuse to leave the house and asked to catch up with her neighbor another day. She later realized the blanked smelled like Smells So Fresh. How did a laundry detergent have that much power over Yasmin? It’s because her brain learned a long time ago that the smell of the detergent meant someone was getting hurt or that she may be hurt. It was such a negative experience for Yasmin with such big consequences, that she still feels the effects today. The illustration below shows you this process.

questions.prompt: What things remind you of a traumatic event you've experienced? Jot down certain smells, sounds, objects, people, and places that come to mind. Some may be more obvious to you than others, so take a few minutes to think about it.

fields.text: Smells:
Objects:
People:
Places:
Now, choose one of these reminders to use in the following exercise.
Type one difficult or traumatic event that you are often reminded of:
Type the thing (the smell, the sound, the object, the place etc.) that reminds you of the event you described in the previous question:
Finally, type the thoughts and feelings you had at the time of the event:

Think back to the traumatic event: was the thing that you wrote (the smell, the sound, the object, the place, etc.) occurring or present at the same time? If so, a link now exists even without directly encountering the traumatic event again. Just like the smell of laundry by itself caused Yasmin to feel anxious and fearful, even though no one was harming her or anyone else.

In the next set of questions, only focus on your thoughts and feelings that you now experience when you encounter the reminder (the smell, the sound, the object, the place, etc.). For Yasmin, the smell of laundry detergent (the thing she smells) still leads to a sense of dread and anxiety.
What is your reminder (the smell, the sound, the object, the place, etc.)?
What do you experience now when you come across the reminder?

So, the next time your emotions come up again without you realizing it, think about the triggers that may be in your environment. Sometimes, you might have vivid flashbacks of the event when you are triggered by something in your environment. Unchecked emotional responses to trauma can snowball until you’re unable to stop it.

pages.text:
It may not feel true, but there ARE ways to avoid lashing out or hurting others when dealing with trauma, whether you are just feeling sad thinking about what happened, or you're having a full flashback to your trauma. Your mental traffic light can help you figure out how serious your trauma reaction is and what you need to do to feel better and avoid hurting someone else. Here’s what to keep in mind when evaluating whether your reaction is green, yellow, or red.
  • Green Trauma Reactions - when you have emotions (sadness, anger) about your trauma, but you still feel in control of your thoughts and actions. When this happens, use coping skills you have learned in other modules, like Thought Stopping or Deep Breathing, to regain control of your emotions.
  • Yellow Trauma Reactions - when you have strong emotions or impulses related to your trauma that are hard to fight, like the urge to shove someone who reminds you of your abuser. If you are thinking of ways to justify your behavior, such as ”he's talking the same way my abuser did, so he's probably a piece of shit anyways,” remember this is a form of criminal thinking and is a bad sign! Turn this behavior green by walking away from the situation and talking to someone who can help you. Leave the store, walk to the bus stop, call your supervising officer, or visit a friend. Then, use coping skills you have learned in other modules, like Thought Stopping and Cognitive Restructuring to calm yourself down and think about what caused your trauma reaction.
  • Red Trauma Reaction - when you have such intense or overwhelming thoughts and feelings related to your trauma that you lose track of what's happening around you, like flashbacks or reliving the event. For example, when someone drives down the highway and approaches the back of a tow truck, they suddenly visualize themselves smashing into the back of the truck like they did last winter. They suddenly see themselves in their old car and the road they were on at the time of the accident, not the road they are REALLY driving on right now. They've become immersed in a flashback, lost touch with reality, and are not only in great emotional distress, but in physical danger of another car wreck. To turn this Red Trauma Reaction green, the driver needs to stop what they’re doing and pull over to the side of the road. When you are in the red, leave the situation whenever possible and/or use coping skills to bring you back to the present moment, like Meditation and Grounding techniques. Then, call someone you trust, like your supervising officer or a family member, for support and comfort. Once you relax more, you can develop a plan to finish what you need to do and get back to a safe place, like home or to a doctor's appointment, where you can process what happened and get the help you need.
pages.subheader: How to Handle Trauma Reactions without Hurting Others

pages.text: At some point in your past, you may have thought that your traumatic experience gave you the right to be mean to others. Or, you may simply not have known any better. For example, you may have learned to parent in an abusive manner because that’s how you were parented. In fact, you may not have seen your parent’s behaviors as abusive before. But, you know better now. Abuse is not an excuse for abuse. This includes your own abuser(s). Retaliating with violence is not the answer; it will only get YOU in trouble. The only exception is self-defense—when you feel you are in immediate danger and must fight back. Otherwise, go through the appropriate channels to get justice for yourself. Treating others badly because of your own trauma is likely to give them their own trauma to work through. In this way, trauma becomes one vicious, painful cycle. If you have treated someone poorly because of your trauma, you are NOT a bad person! But it DOES give you the opportunity to acknowledge that what you did was not fair to other people and to commit to changing your behavior in the future. Be the one who stops the cycle of violence.
pages.subheader: What is NOT an Acceptable Trauma Reaction?

pages.text: This exercise is meant to help you see whether there is a cycle or pattern of violence in your life. Use the space below to connect your own traumas to others. We will start with the people who have caused you harm in the past, like a parent or romantic partner, as it will be easier. Then, for each of those people, you will consider who may have hurt them. Some abusers you may know ("my mom molested me and she was molested by her own dad"), whereas other abusers you may not know ("maybe the kids that bullied me in high school were bullied themselves"). Just for a moment, put yourself in the abuser's shoes and consider ways in which they might have been mistreated in the past. Finally, you will identify the people who you have hurt over the years as a result of your own mistreatment.

fields.text: List the people who have directly hurt you:
List the people who may have hurt your abuser:
List the people who were hurt by you:

pages.text:
Now that you have looked at the ways in which your environment signals unhelpful trauma reactions, as well as the cycle of abuse and trauma that you were brought into when you were victimized, it's time to stop these cycles once and for all. There are many actions you can choose to take when you feel a trauma reaction coming on. Hopefully they seem familiar—they are coping skills you’ve been practicing throughout the program.
  • Green Actions: choose to express your trauma reactions in a healthy way, like using ”I” statements when talking with others and deciding whether you will act on your feelings in that moment or wait until later when you feel better and can think more clearly.
  • Yellow Actions: use deep breathing and thought stopping to slow down the reaction. Ask yourself what the benefits are to acting on your impulses, and what are the benefits to not acting? Then walk away from the situation.
  • Red Actions: use your five senses to remind you where you really are in that moment. Focus on the things you hear (a dog barking) and feel (an office chair underneath you) that remind you that the trauma is NOT happening over again. Use deep breathing to regain control of your body. Then, get yourself to a safe place, like a room by yourself, the side of the road, or outside the grocery store where you can continue to focus on breathing and call someone you trust.

fields.text: What behaviors can you commit to changing right now to stop the trauma cycle?

pages.text:
When something bad happens to us, we might experience things like victim blame or survivor’s guilt. Victim blame could come from you (blaming yourself) or from other people (such as blaming your fashion choices for being sexually assaulted). Survivor’s guilt looks something like this: ”Why was I spared but others weren’t? Why do I deserve to live?” What someone wore during a trauma doesn’t matter and we will never know why some people leave this world earlier than others. Because something bad happened to you, you are a victim by definition. Nothing can change what happened in the past or why you’re still sitting here today. But, what you call yourself matters.
Seeing yourself as a victim does not have to be the only way to describe yourself for the rest of your life! In fact, victims have a RESPONSIBILITY to themselves to work through their trauma and grow from their experiences, no matter how negative. This is especially true when your attitudes and behavior impact your relationships with other people or your ability to complete supervision.
pages.subheader: Moving Your Story Forward: Victim or Survivor?

questions.prompt: What comes to mind when you hear the word ”victim”? Think of feelings, pictures, and common experiences for people described as victims. Don’t think too hard, type the first thing that pops up.

fields.text: Feelings:
Pictures:
Common experiences:

People who are victims of trauma have the chance to change their story. Before Oji realized he needed to create a different world, he explored other worlds to see where he fit best. During that time, he witnessed terrible events—war, starvation, and emptiness. Seeing such awful conditions that his fellow beings lived in kept him awake at night, tossing and turning. He was so upset at the thought of others’ suffering, he started going crazy with worry. When he developed into a supernatural being, Oji had a choice to make: do I continue worrying about other people and creatures who are unhappy, or do I act? Considering Oji’s beautiful world of mountains, grassy plains, and peaceful waters, you can imagine which option he chose!
Though you aren’t supernatural, you have powers within yourself. In the same way Oji chose to make a better life for other living things and himself, you can choose to tell your story in a way that makes you feel more empowered. For example, instead of thinking of yourself as a victim, think of yourself as a survivor. Being a survivor doesn’t mean that what happened to you is okay or right. It just puts the spotlight on your successes, what you did well, and how you are making a better life for yourself. You survived and persevered. You didn’t lay down and die. There is nothing wrong with being a victim—but lots of progress comes from being a survivor. Survivors find healthy ways to learn from their experiences and carry on.
Now think of the word ”survivor.” What comes to mind? Think of feelings, pictures, and common experiences for people described as survivors.
Feelings:
Pictures:
Common experiences:
So, do you see yourself as a trauma victim or are you a survivor?

pages.text:
When you take a story about a victim and reframe it to describe a survivor, you are ”restorying” the story. When you restory a story, the key facts—the who, what, when, and where—stay the same. But the way the victim is described changes. You can describe what they did to overcome the attacker or the disaster. You can make them sound like a hero! Let’s try to restory Joetta’s story.
”Joetta was 15 years old when Hurricane Katrina hit Louisiana. The hurricane caused the water levels to rise, which forced the levies, or dams, holding back water to break. As a result, Joetta’s house flooded. Water rushed in through the windows and doors of Joetta’s home at an unbelievable speed. Joetta fled her house with her dad. When she looked around, she realized her mom and brother had not fled with them. Joetta screamed for them to come out of the house. Joetta’s dad went back into the house to look for them. She stood on the sidewalk crying for what seemed like forever. Eventually Joetta’s dad came out of the house again, carrying her little brother’s lifeless body. Joetta’s mom walked out after him, then fell to the ground and screamed. It felt like time stopped for Joetta—she couldn’t do anything except stare at her dead brother. Her ears were ringing. She could hear her mom’s screams only vaguely. Now, at the age of 30 years old, Joetta still thinks back on that day. She can hear the screaming like it was yesterday, and sees realistic images of how her brother looked that day. She has dreams that include drowning, waking up in her childhood bed to the sound of rushing water, and that her brother’s dead body will wash up inside her house, staring at her, bumping against her feet. Joetta will start to cry uncontrollably when she thinks about that day, and whenever someone talks about flooding or hurricanes happening in other states, she tells people that she lost everything to Hurricane Katrina—including her family.”

fields.text: What was the traumatic event Joetta experienced?
How did the event affect Joetta and her family?

Now, restory Joetta’s story. Write the facts in a way that makes Joetta look like a hero. (Hint: when restorying someone’s story, the bad things that happen don’t change. You just focus on what the person did well or how much progress they have made since the event).

In the same way you restoryed Joetta's story, here's your chance to restory your OWN story. Write the facts of your trauma in a way that makes you look and feel like a hero. Remember, focus on what you did well and the amount of progress you've made since that happened. Because it can be hard to see the ways in which you are the hero of your own story, ask someone you trust who knows what happened (a sibling, friend, or supervising officer) to tell you what they think you did right in the event. You may be surprised to hear how many positive things they have to say about you!
In doing this exercise, what strengths have you identified in yourself that you didn't know were there before?

pages.text:
Some people who experience trauma may be bothered by the event for a long time, and the trauma may affect their lives in ways outlined in this module. The trauma may be upsetting or troublesome, but they are still able to go to work or school and take care of themselves. Other people who experience trauma have difficulty going to work, school, the store, or taking care of themselves each day because of the stress and despair that their trauma caused them. This ”next-level” trauma response can also cause people to experience some or all of the following:
  • Vivid flashbacks that are like reliving the experience.
  • Feeling disconnect from yourself, like an outer-body experience, or being in slow motion (this is often called dissociation).
  • Thoughts that you, your thoughts, or your emotions aren't real.
  • Thoughts that your life or the world isn't real.
  • Seeing, hearing, or feeling things that remind you of the trauma make you really angry, nervous, or upset.
  • Thoughts of harming yourself or other people.
  • Constantly checking your surroundings or feeling paranoid the trauma could happen again at any moment.

The symptoms that come with next-level trauma make it hard to complete community supervision because you may avoid leaving your house, finding a job, or meeting with your supervising officer. When next-level trauma symptoms are triggered, it can be hard to keep your cool, especially in public places. Trauma symptoms can cause people to act out in a verbally or physically aggressive way. Other people may see you as someone who is angry, yelling, or possibly threatening violence when you are really just hurting and don’t know how to stop the trauma reminders. In extreme cases, you may hurt someone accidentally or without realizing it, which jeopardizes your probation. If your probation officer or counselor don’t know you’ve experienced a trauma and that symptoms related to that trauma are concerns for you, they will not know how to help you if something happens in the future. This is why is it important to at least remind your officer that you are working on this module. Experiencing many of these trauma symptoms at an extreme level may mean you have trauma-related mental illness.
pages.subheader: Next-Level Trauma Symptoms: When Trauma Reaches the Next Level

pages.text: You may have heard of a mental illness called Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder or PTSD. These letters get thrown around a lot, especially when talking about military veterans. Experiencing a trauma does not necessarily mean you will qualify for a diagnosis of PTSD. PTSD can only be diagnosed by a mental health professional, like a licensed psychologist, using well-developed tests. There is another lesser known trauma disorder called Acute Stress Disorder. It is like PTSD, but the symptoms do not last as long. Like PTSD, a mental health professional has to diagnose this disorder. Do not diagnose yourself based on the information in this module or anything you may read on the internet. If you have been diagnosed with either of these before, or if you are worried you might have PTSD or Acute Stress Disorder, talk to your supervising officer and schedule an appointment with a mental health professional to talk about your concerns.
pages.subheader: What is PTSD? Fact vs. Fiction

pages.text: It’s important to check in with yourself to see if you are experiencing more extreme symptoms related to a traumatic event. At the beginning of this program, you answered a question about experiencing a traumatic event. Think back to your answer.

fields.text: In what ways do the symptoms that you said ”yes” to impact your everyday life? Think about work, school, computer supervision, family, and friendships.

Up until now, how have you learned to cope with these symptoms and their effect on you? Include both helpful ways (avoiding things that remind you of the trauma) and unhelpful ways (getting high when you think too much about the trauma).
Now that you have reached the end of the module, what are some new ways that you heave dealt with these symptoms?
How will you use the skills you learned in this module to deal with them differently?

pages.text:
The assessment you took when starting the program also provides an overall score to measure how severe your trauma-related symptoms are for you. Higher scores suggest more difficulty dealing with trauma. Your score can be used to help you decide whether you should talk to a professional about further addressing your trauma experiences. Navigate to the assessment center and find your score on the Assessment of Stressful Experiences.
If your number is above 44, then you are likely experiencing several symptoms of next-level trauma that are impacting your everyday life in big ways. However, if you have military experience, you should be concerned if your number is 50 or higher. If your score is above these numbers, please talk to your supervising officer about seeing a counselor or joining ama treatment group that specializes in helping people work through trauma support group. You should not travel down this road alone. Even if you think you can handle it. Remember—that kind of thinking is a red light AND an example of criminal thinking because you are not taking appropriate responsibility to deal with a potentially dangerous situation.
The intention of these worksheets is to provide information on trauma - THIS IS NOT THE END OF TRAUMA WORK. If these worksheets helped you think more about your trauma and brought out big, difficult emotions, then take steps to continue working on your trauma. Even if your score on this measure was less than 44. Your responses to trauma are your own and are not defined by a number. However, measures like this can give you some additional perspective. This is not the last time you are expected to ever think about your trauma! You now have some knowledge and skills about trauma—as it's up to you to continue your journey to trauma recovery.

fields.text: My score on the Assessment of Stressful Experiences:
Do you think your score would be the same if you answered the same questions again today?
Why or why not?

pages.text:
Free Phone/Tablet Apps Available for Download:
PTSD Coach (Free)
  • iTunes and Google Play
  • o Learn about and cope with the symptoms related to PTSD that commonly occur following trauma.
PTSD Family Coach (Free)
  • iTunes and Google Play
  • Support family members of those living with PTSD.
Mindfulness Coach (Free)
  • iTunes and Google Play
  • Provides mindfulness training that could relieve some PTSD symptoms
Vetchange (Free)
  • iTunes
  • o Veterans, Servicemembers, and anyone who is concerned about their drinking and how it relates to posttraumatic stress after deployment.
CPT Coach
  • iTunes and Google Play
  • o Helps you work with your therapist during Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT). CPT Coach is not a self-help tool.
PE Coach
  • iTunes and Google Play
  • o Used during Prolonged Exposure (PE) therapy with a mental health professional. PE Coach is not a self-help tool.
CBT-i Coach (Free)
  • iTunes and Google Play
  • o Helps you get the most out of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia. CBT-i Coach is best used while in therapy with a provider.
pages.subheader: Resource List: More Help Coping With Trauma

pages.text:
National Alliance Mental Illness Helpline
  • 1-800-950-NAMI (6264)
PTSD Helpline
  • 1-800-273-8255 press ”1” if you are a veteran
Military Helpline
  • 1-888-HLP-4-VET (1-888-457-4838)
PTSD information voicemail
  • 802-296-6300
National Child Abuse Hotline
  • 1-800-422-4453 press ”1” to speak with a counselor
Depression Hotline
  • 1-630-482-9696
National Suicide Prevention Lifeline
  • 988 (24/7 service)

In this Module you learned about:
  • What trauma is and how it affects thoughts, feelings, and behavior
  • The importance of working through trauma to be successful on community supervision
  • Your own symptoms of trauma and Sinkholes related to the event
  • Skills like the lockbox and restorying skills to help you resolve trauma

fields.text: Which of the goals that you learned about in this module are you going to focus on this week?
How will you accomplish your goal?
What might get in your way of accomplishing it?
What skills will you use to move past your road block?

pages.text: Now let's see what you learned! This quiz has 9 questions. Select the BEST possible answer to each question. Remember, you need to earn a score of 75% or above to move on to the next module!

questions.prompt: 1. One goal of this module is to make your bad memories go away forever.

fields.text: 1. One goal of this module is to make your bad memories go away forever.
2. Which of the following is NOT true about trauma?

answers.answer: a.	Professional help and time can heal trauma
b.	Women are more likely to be sexually assaulted than men
c.	It is never a good idea to talk about your trauma experiences
d.	Victims of trauma often blame themselves for what happened

fields.text: 3.	Only physical harm can cause trauma.
4.	In the United States, relatively few people have been exposed to a traumatic event in their lifetime.
5.	What is trauma avoidance?

answers.answer: a.	A series of safety tips to prevent experiencing trauma
b.	Putting thoughts and feelings about trauma aside and not wanting to think or talk about them
c.	Refusing to work in a job that may expose you to trauma
d.	Successfully going through life without experiencing any trauma

fields.text: 6.	Traumatic events can change your beliefs about…

answers.answer: a.	Your ability to control your environment
b.	What it means to get close with others

fields.text: 7.	Sinkholes are negative ways of thinking that stem from traumatic events and can keep you from feeling better and moving on.
8.	All of the following are important signs that you may need more intensive treatment for your trauma, <u>except</u>…

answers.answer: a.	Having excessive amounts of energy and feeling ”invincible”
b.	Vivid flashbacks that are like reliving the traumatic event
c.	Thoughts that your life or the world around you isn’t real
d.	Constantly checking your surroundings or feeling paranoid about the trauma happening again

fields.text: 9.	If you want or need more help overcoming my trauma, you can…

answers.answer: a.	Talk to someone you trust about what I need
c.	Find a therapist in my area

questions.prompt: 2. Which of the following is <u>NOT</u> true about trauma?

answers.answer: a. Professional help and time can heal trauma
b. Women are more likely to be sexually assaulted than men
c. It is never a good idea to talk about your trauma experiences
d. Victims of trauma often blame themselves for what happened

questions.correctAnswer: c. It is never a good idea to talk about your trauma experiences

questions.prompt: 3. Only physical harm can cause trauma.
4. How common is it to have experienced a traumatic event in the US?

answers.answer: a. It's rare, very few people in the US have experienced trauma
b. It's very common, as many as half of adults in the US have experienced trauma

questions.correctAnswer: b. It's very common, as many as half of adults in the US have experienced trauma

questions.prompt: 5. What is trauma avoidance?

answers.answer: a. A series of safety tips that lower the chances you’ll be a victim of trauma
b. Putting thoughts and feelings about trauma aside and not wanting to think about or talk about them
c. Work in a job that may expose you to trauma
d. Successfully going through life without experiencing any trauma

questions.correctAnswer: b. Putting thoughts and feelings about trauma aside and not wanting to think about or talk about them

questions.prompt: 6. Traumatic events can change your beliefs about...

answers.answer: a. Your ability to control your environment
b. What it means to get close with others

b. Vivid flashbacks that are like reliving the traumatic event
c. Thoughts that your life or the world around you isn't real
d. Constantly checking your surroundings or feeling paranoid about the trauma happening again

answers.answer: a. Talk to someone you trust about what I need
c. Find a therapist in my area
